11:13 am
PM

The Brexit vote and the short but messy period in British politics immediately after June 23 present serious downside risks to the near-term outlook. The limited soft data for the period since the UK voted to leave the EU has been mixed so far. Confidence indicators and Bank of England field work point to resilient demand, and stagnation rather than recession in the coming quarters. But the PMI data for July released today point to a sharp drop in economic activity. The risk of a recession in H2 2016 is significant. We expect the Bank of England to respond to this threat with a fairly aggressive stimulus package at the upcoming Inflation Report on the 4 August. We look for a 25bps rate cut with a 60% chance of QE – circa £100bn.

PM

Berenberg

PM

Record drops in output and orders

Output and orders for the composite PMI index fell by the most on record in July. While manufacturing outperformed services compared to consensus expectations, indexes for both sectors were below the crucial 50 mark - in the past, the 50 threshold has proved to be a fairly reliable indicator for growth (see chart). In services, activity and new orders fell by the most since the financial crisis. For manufacturers, while the weaker sterling saw new export orders rise at the highest rate in two years, purchase price inflation increased by the fastest rate in 5 years.

11:14 am
PM

A knee-jerk reaction to political uncertainty

The Brexit vote has dragged our weighted average of the services and manufacturing PMIs to the lowest level since April 2009 (see chart). If today’s PMI reading proves to be reliable, it indicates a rate of decline in economic activity last seen only during the financial crisis. Our hunch is that the PMIs have overreacted somewhat as they are in contrast to other soft data since June 23. A report published earlier this week by the Bank of England pointed to a slowdown in activity since the referendum, rather that a sharp contraction. Similarly, while consumer confidence for July dropped at its sharpest rate for over twenty years, it fell from a high level and remained consistent with a slowdown rather than a decline in household consumption.

PM

V or U shaped recovery?

Two additional points are worth noting. First, although the UK economy was accelerating over the course of 2015, PMI data were trending down – suggesting a pessimistic bias in the index. Second, strong expectations, ex-ante, that the impact of the Brexit-vote could be very negative in the short-term could be feeding into purchasing manager’s current assessments. Financial market volatility has been limited beyond the initially sharp falls, consumer confidence remains resilient, and domestic political risks have diminished quickly with the sooner-than-expected election of a Prime Minister (PM). That the new PM Theresa May has spent the past few days shaking hands and smiling on camera with Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande will bolster expectations of an amicable divorce from the EU. Altogether, this suggests a V shaped recovery in economic activity and sentiment rather than a protracted U shaped slump. Next month’s data should be better – watch this space closely.

PM

Oh I see, these PMI figs are "flash" readings

11:15 am
PM

A special to give people an early snapshot of the Brexit effect

PM

Note: IHS Markit has, for the first time, produced ‘flash’ UK PMI estimates as a result of the 23 June EU referendum outcome to provide an indication of firm sentiment post-result. These estimates, however, are based on approximately 70% of expected responses. Fuller ‘final’ estimates will be released as per usual during the first week of August, and as such the ‘flash’ estimates may be subject to change.

PM

This is Barclays

11:16 am
PM

Firm sentiment declined markedly on the outcome of the 23 June referendum on EU membership according to the ‘flash’ PMI estimates. The ‘flash’ Composite PMI headline index (output) declined to 47.7 from 52.3, its lowest reading since April 2009. This was driven by both services and manufacturing, where output declined by 4.9pts (to 47.4) and by 3.8pts (to 49.1), respectively. While output fell markedly across the board, even sharper drops in forward-looking components were recorded, such as new orders and business or business expectations, pointing to even more downside to come.

PM

As the impact from the referendum result sets in, and already elevated levels of uncertainty spiral higher on a lack of clarity regarding the UK’s post-exit relationship with the EU and the rest of the world in the near term, confidence levels are likely to fall further in our view. This will force businesses to become even more cautious with regard to hiring, spending and investment decisions, worsening their ability to attract new business, thus confirming our cautious outlook on economic activity. This is partially underscored already by service business expectations which recorded its sharpest fall on record, to levels last seen during the financial crisis. Given this backdrop, we forecast that the UK is likely to enter a shallow and prolonged recession from Q3 16, contracting by on average -0.1% q/q until the end of our forecast horizon. In contrast, according to the IHS Markit PMI press release, today’s figures would be consistent with a 0.4% contraction in Q3 16.

PM

It is encouraging that the +2.2% YoY change in group service revenue in 1Q FY17 was better than the consensus estimate compiled by VOD (VOD LN, 236p*, Neutral, FV 210p) of +1.9%. Even so, we think the share price reaction so far today (c.+5% currently) is overly exuberant. This is mainly because of the sum of the following:

PM

Consensus forecasts are unlikely to change meaningfully after today’s event because (i) the beat was small; (ii) today’s update was about revenue metrics only (during the call VOD implied opex rose in 1Q FY17, for example); (iii) VOD simply reiterated FY17 guidance.

Also, according to Bloomberg, the consensus price target of all sell-side analysts is 243p, only +8% vs. VOD’s share price at the open this morning.

11:27 am
PM

VOD believes YoY growth in group service revenue in 2Q FY17 will be less than that reported today for 1Q FY17. This is because of extra regulatory drag and tough YoY comparisons in some markets (e.g. in Spain and South Africa).

• VOD highlighted still aggressive competition in Germany and Italy (we estimate these two markets account for 22% and 12% of VOD’s group value respectively).

Because of this, we think it is important to hear what key rivals in these markets plan for their respective futures. DT will report on 11 August, and TI on 27 July (also TEF and BT will report on 28 July).

• Just today VOD India announced ‘more (data allowance) for the same (price)’ measures ahead of Reliance Jio entering the market later in 2016.

We estimate VOD India is the group’s third most valuable asset (c.12% of group value).

• On our FY17 forecasts, VOD currently trades on a P/E of 34.8x vs. the sector on 16.6x, 6.5x EV/EBITDA vs. the sector on 6.2x and a 5.3% dividend yield vs. 2.6% FCFE yield and 2.4x net debt/EBITDA.

11:36 am
PM

Ok, got the detail from Neil now

PM

So you can work through it carefully -- cos nothing with Rocket is straightforward

PM

According to a statement from Home 24 Rocket Internet, Kinnevik and Holtzbrinck Ventures invested a further EUR 20m into Home24 at the start of the quarter. Despite this it appears Kinnevik has reduced the Fair Value of their investment twice in two quarter. At the end of 2015 the Kinnevik stake in Home 24 was valued at SEK 801M, then at SEK 492M in Q1 to SEK 96M in Q2. This latest cut is a full -80% between Q1 and Q2. Kinnevik have marked a change in the fair value in unlisted assets as a result of continued multiple contraction in public market peer valuations and Kinnevik has lower ranked shares.

11:37 am
PM

The Home24 mark down is a because the combination of additional capital and other investments and mark to market valuation and with Kinnevik adhering to IFRS standards the company has to mark the value down. Key Home & Living peer valuation decreased from 1.3x to 1x during Q2. Kinnevik apply a straight line read across to Home24 and discount a similar reduction in enterprise calculation of Home 24. There is an amount of capital raised and consumed which sits ahead of Kinnevik capital given long time ago. So earlier Kinnevik equity capital gets diminished in theoretical IFRS calculations. Kinnevik attempt to caveat the same by suggesting that they are not as diluted by recent funding as IFRS impairment implies (aka value is higher if Home24 IPOs in time). But we are only aware of a small EUR 20 m raise in total for Home 24 in the last six months.

PM

Now we aren't privy to these liquidation preferences or whether Rocket's investments are senior to Kinnevik and depressing Kinnevik's stake value. But by 80%? That seems unlikely. Home24's adjusted EBITDA margin decreased from -30.8% in 2014 to -32.2% in 2015, due to ongoing investments into future growth. Adjusted EBITDA changed from EUR -49.4 million in 2014 to EUR -75.3 million in 2015. (Rocket Statement). Rocket's LPV at the end of April 2016 carried a 44.6% stake in Home 24. This implied a valuation of EUR 980M for Home 24 and contributing EUR440M to Rocket's own LPV. This is the fourth largest individual LPV company in the Rocket portfolio and amounts to c15% of Rocket market cap, or 9% of their last LPV. According to Rocket's own LPV reports the last financing round for Home24 was in March 2016, on which this LPV calculation is based. Prior to this Rocket's disclosure shows Rocket's stake was 46.4% on a last financing round at EUR 940m valuation in May 2015.

PM

The last considerable mark down by Rocket was in GFG, from EUR 3 billion to EUR 1 billion on the last financing round which just happened to have been led by Kinnevik. Is Kinnevik not contributing to Home 24 based on valuation discrepancies we wonder? We don't know. All we do know is that there remains enough opaqueness around the differences in implied valuations on Rocket Internet's LPV. We already feel that the other biggest contributors to Rocket LPV, Hello Fresh and Delivery Hero are too high in carried value given the industry back drop and financial metrics. With weak business momentum, opaque funding structures and the rising risk of down rounds in portfolio companies we remain bearish on Rocket Internet. Sell.

11:43 am
PM

We have cut our FY16 PBT from £519m to £497m. This is a fairly straight forward exercise.
Constant currency (CC) Q4 yield to date is currently at -7.5% yoy; at this same rate,
reported FY16 revenues will be down 2.1% yoy to £4.59bn. FY16 ex-fuel CC cost guidance is
-1% yoy; on a reported basis this equates to total costs of £4.092bn. Less net financing this
equates to a PBT of £497m.
Given this, we assume there will be a significant cut in consensus numbers, which stood at
£584m for those published post-Brexit but before yesterday’s release. Additionally, while
pre-Brexit Q4 yields were being booked at ~5% down yoy, post-Brexit yields are currently
down circa 13% yoy. If that rate continued for the rest of Q4 then our NPAT number would
be down to £463m.

PM

Given Q4 yield uncertainty, easyJet took the unusual step of providing no full year pretax
profit guidance. Despite that, comments on strong brand, strong balance sheet and cost
control dominated (although flat FY15-FY19 cost guidance was repeated). We question if an
unchanged growth plan is reasonable given the risk of the UK being in recession next year.
This would suggest that easyJet’s medium term CAGR capacity growth should be closer to
5.5%, not the 7.8% currently planned.
Looking forward, FY17 should benefit from some recovery of the £125m NPAT loss
ytd from external events. Further, fuel benefits will continue to accrue. However,
risk of a UK recession, hedges which will delay the benefit of FX moves on yields to
FY18 and the likelihood that other carriers will still be discounting fares next year
makes any recovery hard to call. With FY16f valuations at average levels, we retain
our Hold.

PM
